phrases.text: Gió đánh ố mấy đưa đò đưa Gió đập ố mấy đưa đò đưa
phrases.english: Wind hit/beat oh how many ferry/transport ferry ferry/transport Wind pound/beat oh how many ferry/transport ferry ferry/transport

culturalContext.description: This quan họ phrase is from UNESCO-recognized courtship song tradition of Bắc Ninh. Historically sung alternately between male and female groups during village festivals and boat outings. As the opening phrase, this establishes the song's emotional tone and invites audience engagement. This phrase repeats multiple times throughout the song, serving as a structural anchor and allowing audience participation.
facts: Quan họ originated in 49 villages of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang provinces, UNESCO heritage since 2009
Traditionally performed on decorated boats (thuyền hoa) during spring festivals
Singers wore distinctive costumes: women in four-panel dress (áo tứ thân), men in turbans
Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
culturalContext.musicalContext: As the opening phrase, it establishes the tonal center and introduces the melodic motif that will be varied throughout. The repetition of this refrain creates hypnotic effect and marks structural divisions between narrative verses.

phrases.text: Sao cô là cô mình mãi ư lửng lơ mà chưa có chồng (lửng lơ mà chưa có chồng)
phrases.english: why/how Miss/aunt is/be Miss/aunt oneself mãi [?] (particle) hover/hang (exclamation) that/which not yet have/there is stack/husband (name: (lửng) (exclamation) that/which not yet have/there is chồng) [?]

culturalContext.description: Husband-complaint songs are a traditional Vietnamese genre allowing women to humorously express marriage frustrations. The exaggerated complaints (too small, too lazy, snoring) provide social catharsis. This quan họ phrase is from UNESCO-recognized courtship song tradition of Bắc Ninh. Historically sung alternately between male and female groups during village festivals and boat outings.
facts: Wife-complaining-about-husband songs were traditionally sung during women's communal work (weaving, husking rice)
The exaggerated descriptions (tiny husband, lazy husband) follow comedic folk song conventions - not literal complaints
These songs provided psychological relief in patriarchal society where women had limited public voice
Quan họ originated in 49 villages of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang provinces, UNESCO heritage since 2009

phrases.text: Gió đánh ố mấy vông cành vông Gió đập ố mấy vông cành vông

culturalContext.description: "Ông" is a respectful address for married men. Its use in this context shows the formal politeness maintained in Vietnamese, even when criticizing one's husband. This quan họ phrase is from UNESCO-recognized courtship song tradition of Bắc Ninh. Historically sung alternately between male and female groups during village festivals and boat outings.
facts: Quan họ originated in 49 villages of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang provinces, UNESCO heritage since 2009
Traditionally performed on decorated boats (thuyền hoa) during spring festivals
Singers wore distinctive costumes: women in four-panel dress (áo tứ thân), men in turbans
Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura

culturalContext.description: "Em" indicates a younger person or term of endearment in romance. In folk songs, it often represents the female voice addressing herself or being addressed by a lover. This quan họ phrase is from UNESCO-recognized courtship song tradition of Bắc Ninh. Historically sung alternately between male and female groups during village festivals and boat outings.

culturalContext.musicalContext: The 6-syllable structure (song lục) balances melody with text, common in Southern traditions.

culturalContext.description: This quan họ phrase is from UNESCO-recognized courtship song tradition of Bắc Ninh. Historically sung alternately between male and female groups during village festivals and boat outings. As the closing phrase, this provides resolution and often returns to opening themes for circular structure.
facts: Quan họ originated in 49 villages of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang provinces, UNESCO heritage since 2009
Traditionally performed on decorated boats (thuyền hoa) during spring festivals
Singers wore distinctive costumes: women in four-panel dress (áo tứ thân), men in turbans
Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
culturalContext.musicalContext: The 5-syllable structure (lục bát's "lục" variant) adds weight and conclusion, often used at phrase endings. As the closing phrase, it typically returns to the tonic note and may quote the opening melody for circular structure.
